articles.headline: McCain Plan to Aid States on Health Could Be Costly
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain’s plan to expand federal support for state high-risk pools could run into his pledge to balance the budget.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain’s plan to expand federal support for state high-risk pools could run into his pledge to balance the budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: PIKESVILLE, Md.  If Senator John McCain’s radical plan for remaking American health care is to work, he will have to find a way to cover people like Chaim Benamor, 52, a self-employed renovator in this Baltimore suburb. Mr. Benamor never found it necessary to buy insurance before having a mild heart attack last year and now, 13 years shy of Medicare, has little hope of doing so.

articles.headline: Surprisingly, Oil Declines for 2nd Day
articles.snippet: The price of crude oil fell $5.33, to $136.04 a barrel, on Tuesday, sending stocks higher. Its 6 percent decline this week has set off a debate among skeptical analysts about whether the price has really peaked.
articles.abstract: The price of crude oil fell $5.33, to $136.04 a barrel, on Tuesday, sending stocks higher. Its 6 percent decline this week has set off a debate among skeptical analysts about whether the price has really peaked.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices headed in an unusual direction — down — for the second consecutive day on Tuesday, leaving energy experts to wonder whether the drop is the beginning of a lasting trend or just a brief pause before another surge.

articles.headline: Retail Chain Said to Face Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Steve & Barry’s, the clothing chain made famous for its cheap celebrity fashion, is preparing to file for bankruptcy protection, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.abstract: Steve & Barry’s, the clothing chain made famous for its cheap celebrity fashion, is preparing to file for bankruptcy protection, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve & Barry’s, the clothing chain that tried to undercut competitors by selling celebrity fashion and shoes for less than $10, was preparing to file for bankruptcy protection late Tuesday in the latest blow to shopping malls battered by the economic downturn.

articles.headline: To Avoid Stalling Out, G.M. Plumbs Its Resources
articles.snippet: General Motors’ cash cushion seems far from comfortable given the extraordinary drop in auto sales.
articles.abstract: General Motors’ cash cushion seems far from comfortable given the extraordinary drop in auto sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Like a gas-thirsty S.U.V. crawling to the pump, General Motors needs to fill up fast with cash.

articles.headline: Fed Sees Turmoil Persisting Deep Into Next Year
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke outlined a series of steps the Fed is considering to stem the housing and financial crises.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke outlined a series of steps the Fed is considering to stem the housing and financial crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal policy makers have concluded that the turmoil plaguing the housing and financial markets is likely to spill deep into 2009, becoming one of the most significant domestic problems to confront the next president when he steps into the White House in January.

articles.headline: Qatar, Playing All Sides, Is a Nonstop Mediator
articles.snippet: In an increasingly divided Arab world, the Qataris have fashioned a reputation as independent arbitrators.
articles.abstract: In an increasingly divided Arab world, the Qataris have fashioned a reputation as independent arbitrators.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — In the past month, after Qatari diplomats brokered a landmark peace deal for Lebanon in talks here, this tiny emirate on the Persian Gulf has enjoyed a brief moment of giddy celebrity.

articles.headline: Obama Donors Aren’t Rushing to Aid Clinton
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama’s top donors have raised less than $100,000 to help erase Senator Hillary Clinton’s debt, “a paltry sum,” in the words of one Clinton official.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama’s top donors have raised less than $100,000 to help erase Senator Hillary Clinton’s debt, “a paltry sum,” in the words of one Clinton official.
articles.lead_paragraph: A prominent donor to Senator Barack Obama recently sent an e-mail plea to other supporters, asking them  for the sake of Democratic unity  to write checks to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to help retire her $23 million in campaign debt.

articles.headline: Study Finds Flawed Practices at Ratings Firms
articles.snippet: A blistering report issued by the S.E.C. found that major rating firms flouted conflict of interests guidelines and considered their own profits when ratings securities.
articles.abstract: A blistering report issued by the S.E.C. found that major rating firms flouted conflict of interests guidelines and considered their own profits when ratings securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The analyst at the credit ratings agency was blunt: “Let’s hope we are all wealthy and retired by the time this house of cards falters.”

articles.headline: For iPhone, the ‘New’ Is Relative
articles.snippet: Apple’s iPhone 3G, which will go on sale on Friday, comes with just a few new bells and whistles.
articles.abstract: Apple’s iPhone 3G, which will go on sale on Friday, comes with just a few new bells and whistles.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year and 11 days ago, our nation was swept by iPhone Mania. TV news coverage was relentless. Hard-core fans camped out to be the first in line. Bloggers referred to Apple’s new product as the “Jesus phone.”

articles.headline: Trial About Privacy in Which None Remains
articles.snippet: Unlike many caught in embarrassing sexual adventures, Max Mosley has chosen to make a public fight.
articles.abstract: Unlike many caught in embarrassing sexual adventures, Max Mosley has chosen to make a public fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  At moments, it seems like British satire at its whimsical, Monty Python-style best: a judge and a bank of lawyers, all stern-as-you-like in horsehair wigs, exploring the finer points of bottom-spanking with an aging multimillionaire and several young women who joined him in a Chelsea flat last winter, for a $5,000 fee, for what was described as five hours of sadomasochistic “fantasy” play.
